Patch Set 20:

(2 comments)
Patch Set 20: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 20:

(3 comments)

I see a lot of PLDMisms that you're trying to push into the dbus interface.  This is a no-go.  I understand PLDM might not map cleanly into our current dbus model, but in no way should application X have to know about PLDM special properties.  Let's fix the whole dbus model if it doesn't work and not try to carve out ways that PLDM is special.

What do you think if I create an interface NumericControl under https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/tree/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Control with a list of properties: Value (writable), MaxValue, MinValue, Unit, TransitionInterval?

This Control folder contains many interfaces that support setting values for different purposes. 

This NumericControl interface will not have bias to PLDM and can also be used to set values to any control object on D-Bus which has common characteristics to a numeric sensor.
For what purpose?
These are not sensors.  Let's not overload that namespace.
Updated.
How do we intend these to be useful to programs?  Arbitrary names and/or string comparisons don't seem very helpful.

I think these effecters better have meaningful names so they can be viewed on Web by users and for users to easily identify and set values to them. Moreover, they needn't always be strings, they are only strings if the PDRs provide the Auxiliary names which is the intention of the platform.
Done
What are we doing about these?  I don't see any proposal.  At least specify you're not handling them yet.
Sorry, this is the design for numeric effecters but I was so into making it generic for both types and forgot to clarify. Commit msg updated.

You need to explain why this is a problem because it isn't obvious to me.

If you want the BMC to _set_ effectors, those are something totally different, aren't they?

I made a mistake saying Sensor.Value is non-writable. I meant that Sensor.Value's supposed to report sensor value, not be used as a control interface. So I think there's a need to have another interface that can be used to set effecters, with some properties under it that applications/users will need to have better knowledge over what they should set to the effecters. Updated to clarify my intention.
Done
Again, why do I care?  "effecter attributes" are something special to PLDM.  I _don't_ want those becoming entrenched in the rest of the code base.

I agree most of the attributes I want to publish are too specific to PLDM, I will remove them.

But I think MinValue, MaxValue, Unit are essential for applications to pre-check the input value before setting it onto D-Bus. Like https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/70301b9c16dc5e3e220472933affb7906b513bf4/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Control/VoltageRegulatorControl.interface.yaml#L17

Besides, TransitionInterval is like a timeout for clients of this interface to know how much time it should wait till the dbus operation completes. Because it expects that the dbus property should only be set after the value is successfully set down to the target place (in this case to the other terminus).

So, I intend to keep the property list of Value, MaxValue, MinValue, Unit, TransitionInterval.

Hi, I scoped out the attributes that are needed to be on DBUS into 4:
xyz.openbmc_project.Effecter.Numeric
  - Value (writable)
  - MaxValue
  - MinValue
  - TransitionInterval
  - Unit [enum]

We see this interface as a means of control that does not take effect directly on BMC, but let any communication protocol write the values to the other end of the communication.

We aim at a design that PLDM service will hold all the sensor and effecter object paths that it manages the reading/writing between BMC and other terminus, and let the consumers of those sensors/effecters interact with them via D-Bus.

We already have the Sensor.Value interface for numeric sensors. We are trying to look for an interface that is generic for OpenBMC but still can represent basic numeric PLDM effecter. We really appreciate if you can give some advice so we can proceed with this and can avoid invasing dbus interface with PLDM terms.
Hi Chau, Thu. Just one immediate comment for now.

See the conversation here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/47252/comment/a1c4b4d9_8b19985e/
Hi @Andrew, I have updated the doc to adapt the latest PS of https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/47252 regarding the D-Bus object path.
since these are static effecters, do we allow the values to be modified aka writable?

Hi, sorry for late response. The previous paragraph is mentioning the devices that do not have PDRs to be achieved via pldm commands to the terminus, so are statically configured in json file. Those effecters are just like normal effecters with a difference in the way the attributes are retrieved. So, those are writable.
